title: I Love You, Now Die: Michelle Carter and Glee's Rachel Berry's link
text:
Michelle Carter was obsessed with Lea Michele’s character Rachel Berry in Glee

(Picture: Rex; Getty)

I Love You, Now Die follows the harrowing true story of Michelle Carter, who goaded her boyfriend Conrad Roy III into killing himself via a series of text messages.

Roy’s body was found by police in 2014, and his girlfriend was then arrested in connection with his death.

The documentary unpicks the events that led to what was to become one of the most conflicting tragedies in recent memory and uncovers a chilling connection between the hit musical comedy Glee and Michelle herself, who appeared to be obsessed with the character of Rachel Berry (Lea Michele).

Michelle Carter was implicated in the death of her boyfriend Conrad Roy III (Picture: Sky Crime)

Journalist Jesse Barron talks in the film about how Carter couldn’t separate fact from fiction, and tried to mirror Berry in her everyday life, including the relationship both on and off screen between Lea Michele and the late Cory Monteith, who died from an accidental overdose in 2013.

The two teenagers only met up in person a handful of time over two years, but grew closer everyday though thousands of destructive texts. As such, their messages were peppered with pop culture references and quotes – most noticeably from Glee.

‘Often when she was writing to Conrad or about Conrad, she would borrow from text that was in this TV show,’ the writer explained. ‘I think she connected with Lea Michele on a kind of profound level that went beyond what a normal teen identifying with a star, you know, may feel like.’

There some harrowing similarities between Michelle Carter’s real-life case and Glee (Picture: REX)

In one message, Carter quotes Berry verbatim by writing: ‘you were my first love, and I wanted more than anything for you to be my last.’ In the context of the show, Michele’s character says this line to her boyfriend – Finn Hudson (Monteith) – before breaking up with him.

Barron also noted an ever more harrowing similarity between the Massachusetts native and her fictional obsession. Conrad’s body was found by police on July 13, 2014. That is exactly one year to the day that Cory Monteith’s body was found by police in a hotel room. The Canadian actor was discovered to have died of an accidental overdose.

Monteith’s death lead to a tribute episode, The Quarterback, and whilst watching the very episode, Carter text Conrad that the episode was ‘just making me realise that someday you may not be here and stuff…’

I Love You, Now Die explores the case (Picture: Sky Crime)

Barron says that this is proof that ‘[she ]had a completely other story going on that has nothing to do with Conrad specifically, That she would be the person in Glee who had a boyfriend who was the quarterback who had sort of tragically died.’

The documentary uncovers that after Roy’s death, Carter used bits of dialogue from Glee and Michele’s own statements from the passing of Monteith in tribute to her real-life ex.

The film’s director, Erin Lee Car, added that the connection to Glee is ‘the clearest example that Michelle Carter was living in a different reality.’

I Love You, Now Die is available to watch on Sky Crime and NOW TV.
